And then this catches my eye while I’m reading today…a compelling reason to go analog.

“Silly gestures” — Why physical Scrum boards and clothespins work

item.title: By: Evan Weinberg
item.dc:creator: Evan Weinberg
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2017/04/07/trello-for-class-organization/#comment-497">Andy "SuperFly" Rundquist</a>.
I'm not sure there's much added value of the analog post-it note. I like the portability of the digital version, and the ease of getting started by copying the new set of tasks. I imagine that the process of copying down tasks would take time that I'm not sure I want to give up. I guess this is something I could ask the students, but I don't expect them to be excited to include a hand-written step.

item.title: By: Andy "SuperFly" Rundquist
item.dc:creator: Andy "SuperFly" Rundquist
item.description:
This is a really cool idea. I've really liked how Trello can help my student research groups work together and understand where things are at. I haven't really used the "sprint" idea from agile, though, and I'm intrigued by what you've said here. The first "could be improved" comment was interesting (seems like self-teaching), especially when coupled with your comment about the different work you had to do.
My question: did the cool tech help or would doing this with post-it notes work as well?
